Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: How Do Thermophilic Proteins Withstand High Temperature?

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:

Scientific Merit: Thermophilic proteins, primarily extracted from organisms that thrive at very high temperatures, denature at significantly higher temperatures than mesophilic proteins from organisms that live at moderate temperatures. One of the long-standing questions in protein science has been: How do selective pressures, such as environmental temperature, impinge on the evolution of thermal tolerance in proteins? With the advent of proteomic and systems level studies that encompass the complete set of proteins in an organism, the question becomes yet more remarkable: How do cells grown at high temperatures adapt their entire collection of proteins? While existing studies are on individual sets of proteins, several experimental data characterizing different proteomes demand new theoretical modeling and detailed analysis at a much larger scale to unravel broad scale adaptive strategies that different organisms may have utilized to withstand such temperature extremities. Such large scale detailed modeling of numerous proteins will be combined with experimental observations as part of this project. The novel multi-scale research will enable computation of several important, hard to measure, yet analyzed biophysical quantities that are central to protein function and stability, ultimately dictating biology. Thus the relationship of microscopic structural features to protein thermodynamics on a global scale will provide essential clues to protein evolution and engineering.

Broader Impact: The project will impact multiple outreach efforts and new initiatives for education. Concepts of protein science, directly related to this work will be integrated in these outreach activities by incorporating in class material, workshop, engaging demonstrations for general public awareness. Graduate curricula and courses will be designed for the newly launched Molecular and Cellular Biophysics doctoral program at the University of Denver in which quantitative modeling in biology including concepts of protein folding, stability and evolution, will be showcased. Simple concepts derived from this research in the form of puzzles, animations and posters will be demonstrated at the science awareness night at the Elitch Garden amusement park, attended by high school students and teachers. This amusement park has a broad appeal across ethnic groups and income levels, and reaches audiences underserved by more traditional outreach methods. These concepts will also be integrated in a short-term training workshop for secondary educators from local schools. Undergraduate students at the University of Denver will carry out parts of the proposal for their senior theses, for which they will be further trained in scientific writing and presentation skills. Results of the research, and codes developed to interpret experimental data will be made freely available online to the global protein science community. Besides immediate impact on protein science, the research will also impact design of new enzymes relevant in protein pharmaceuticals as well as biosynthesis of renewable energy carriers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Thermophilic proteins -- extracted from organisms that live at high temperature -- can withstand much higher temperatures than their mesophilic counterparts primarily extracted from organisms living at or near the room temperature. This is a long-standing puzzle due to very similar sequence and structure shared between thermophilic and mesophilic proteins. We investigated this puzzle by studying the role of the folded and unfolded state combining all-atom simulations with analytically tractable coarse-grained theoretical models. We proposed and performed a large-scale study, in contrast to existing studies that focused on a few protein systems. The rationale was to determine the presence, or absence, of an adaptation principle that may be used at a proteome scale. Previous studies on only a few proteins often suggested conflicting strategies in different proteins, obscuring any general trend and raising the question of how likely a strategy adopted by one protein was to be responsible for adaptation in any other.

We found subtle modulation of charge patterning in the sequence and structure is the primary strategy to gain high thermal tolerance in majority of these proteins. We also revealed the important role of the unfolded/disordered state to this puzzle that remained previously unexplored. 

While studying the role of the unfolded state, we discovered new ways to describe disordered states in proteins. This has lead to new research direction offering novel ways to quantify the shape and size of the Intrinsically Disorderd Proteins (IDP) that lack stable folded structure unlike foldable proteins. IDPs are important since they peform many vital biological functions in higher order organisms including humans. However traditional approaches to study IDPs are limited. Application of our novel theoretical model is begining to provide many insights on how size of these IDPs can be drastically varied by minimal changes with implications to understand function. Furthermore, we have highlighted the need for quality control check while analyzing results from the all-atom simulation data, regularly used by protein science community.

Overall, our research will have broad ranging impact from biotechnology, therapeutics, biofuel production to materials and data science by designing new thermostable enzymes, IDPs, synthetic peptides and polymers with novel properties and new data analysis schemes.

 

Broader Impact: We used novel venues to engage students and the public in developing scientific literacy: the Elitch Garden amusement park and Denver’s NHL Avalanche game. Elitch Garden is the largest amusement park in Denver where, every year, the University of Denver (DU) Society of Physics Students (SPS) chapter demonstrates physics experiments to local high school students, who are given free admission to the park. Demonstrations during the Avalanche game was organized by the Big Brain club. In both settings, SPS students and our lab participated in engaging demonstrations related to protein folding. These ranged from a brief introduction to protein folding problem with movies, an introduction to FoldIt (video games), and protein origami (for example folding papers to form Ion Channels that can open and close). In addition, we hosted high school students from different areas in Denver for day-long visits at DU where they closely interacted with our research team to get more hands on experience with FoldIt, to learn about the protein folding problem, and to visit the High Performance Computing Center (HPC). We collaborated with the University Technology Service (UTS) staff members on how to communicate at the level of school students, using back of the envelope estimates to get a sense of how HPC computing power compared to their smart devices. In these activities graduate students, undergraduate students (SPS) and UTS staff members had an opportunity to reach out to a broader audience. We also regularly involved undergraduate students in research. Seven undergraduate students, including two women over the past six years have worked in our lab. 

In summary, we reached out to high school students, their teachers, parents about the importance of protein science, and computational science. We trained the next generation of students on protein biophysics and several aspects of data science.
